text:
Celebs "Deeply concerned" Ed Sheeran urges fans to snub greedy touts flogging tickets to his gigs for £1,000 The Shape of You singer isn't happy with touts who are denying ordinary fans the chance to see him by hiking up the £77 price Share Ed Sheeran is urging his fans o snub ticket touts (Photo: BPM Media) Share   
Ed Sheeran has urged fans to snub online touts after they flogged tickets to his gigs for up to £1,000 within minutes of going on sale. 
The outrageous hike from the £77 cost sparked fury among those desperate to see the singer-songwriter’s first concerts in two years. 
Thousands were left ­disappointed when tickets quickly sold out – only to reappear on resale websites at the vastly inflated prices. 
A representative for Sheeran said the star was “deeply concerned” by the actions of greedy touts who are denying ordinary fans the chance to see their idol. 
He said: “We urged all fans not to engage with them. We are vehemently opposed to the unethical practices that occur in the secondary market. Ticket selling websites are charging inflated prices 
“We have written to each of our partners, be they promoters, venues or ticketing companies, detailing the way in which we expect tickets to be sold: direct to fans.” 
Last year, the Mirror launched a campaign urging the Government to stop millions of sport, theatre and music fans being ripped off in what has become a £1billion a year industry. Read More Adele fights back against ticket touts by appointing official resale partner 
Pre-sale priority passes for 25-year-old Sheeran’s tour sold out on Tuesday in seconds. But moments later they appeared on resale sites such as StubHub! and Viagogo for £800. 
One fan, Leeds University worker Joss Woodend, posted a screen grab of one being offered at £550. He wrote: “This is why it is impossible to get tickets. The industry is a mess, sort ticket touts out.” 
Others complained of having the tickets in the basket, only for the site to crash. 
But soon afterwards, they were available for the star’s O2 Arena gig in London for £999 plus booking fees. On Seatwave tickets had gone up for sale for up to £636. The Mirror is running a campaign against ticket touts 
Touts operate a slick online ­operation which enables them to snap up thousands of tickets using bot – or robot – attacks that makes websites appear to have crashed during a sale. 
They are then sold to “secondary ticketing” websites, which take a cut of the resale value. 
Appalled singer Paolo Nutini branded the practice, which is not illegal, ­“extortion” as touts cashed in on a ­fundraising gig he sang at in memory of a dead fan. He also urged followers not to buy from them. 
The star added: ­“Regardless of how bad you want to see someone play, don’t support and ­facilitate these sites. 
“This shows how f g shameless some people can be.” Read More Ticket touts frozen out from Who charity cancer gig after Sunday Mirror campaign 
Labour MP Sharon Hodgson, co-chair of the all-party ­parliamentary group for ticket abuse, said: “Many artists, like Ed Sheeran, are doing so much to get tickets into the hands of genuine fans, and not touts. The Government needs to step up and give artists the help they need to put their fans first.” 
Last year, a Parliamentary report found evidence of fraud, criminal activity and massive price hikes in the industry. Ed Sheeran fans are being priced out of seeing him by touts (Photo: Getty) 
Professor Michael Waterson, of Warwick University, who wrote the paper, wants trading standards and police to take action. 
Experts also believe the industry could owe £100million unpaid tax. MPs on the Culture, Media and Sport Committee have called on HMRC to investigate. 
The Competition and Market Authority launched a probe to uncover how the best seats are harvested, then sold at inflated prices, before fans can access them at cost price. 
Since the spotlight was put on the industry some touts have removed tickets from resale sites after their details were published in an attempt to show they are complying with consumer law. Read More 
But others continue to operate despite the attention on their tactics. 
Sheeran has partnered with Twickets.co.uk which allows fans to swap tickets at face value or less. 
Adele last year announced she was teaming up with the site for her sell-out Wembley gigs after fans paid up to a reported £25,000 for a previous tour. 
Ticketmaster said on behalf of Seatwave and Get Me In: “Our priority is to help artists get as many tickets as possible into the hands of real fans.” Adele has also fought back against touts (Photo: Getty) 
A Stubhub spokesman added: “We understand the concerns of artists but the reality is that for many events on our site, the bulk of sellers are fans. 
“The dangers of putting restrictions on fans and how they buy tickets risks in pushing them into the back alleys where there is no consumer protection.” PRIMARY WEBSITES Live Nation The UK’s largest promoter and majority shareholder in Academy Music Group, which owns venues all over the UK, including the 02 Shepherd’s Bush Empire. Ticketmaster Leading primary ticket outlet. Also owns Ticketweb, another major seller. SECONDARY WEBSITES 
Started as a way to help fans unable to go to events to resell to genuine buyers. 
But it the secondary ticketing model was quickly taken advantage of by touts who can set the asking price to whatever they want with the site taking a cut. 
The big four are : Get me in! Bought by Ticketmaster in 2008. Seatwave Snapped up by Ticketmaster in 2014. Stubhub Originally founded by Eric Baker in 2000 but bought by eBay in 2007 for £247million. Has a partnership with The 02 Arena’s box office through ticketing platform AXS.com (owned by promoter AEG). Viagogo Also founded by Baker in 2005. Backed by investors such as Lord Jacob Rothschild. Based in Switzerland having dissolved its UK company. Top of the markups

Eng v France £80 £1,200 Viagogo How it all went wrong for Ed Sheeran fans: 
Tuesday, Jan 31, 10.30am 
After a pre-sale on primary sites with tickets ranging from £45-£75, just minutes later dozens on are on sale on Viagogo and Stubhub for £800. 
Thursday, Feb 2, 9:55am – five minutes before general release 
Approximately 1,500 tickets were listed on resale sites. 
Out of the 1,300 tickets listed on Viagogo, 12 were for a newly added show on 3rd May – however, no tickets had been put on sale for this date at this point. 
The price of a ticket across all three London dates on secondary sites ranged from £200 to £800. 
10am 
General sale tickets go up for between £40 and £75. 
10.05am 
Tickets for all three of Ed’s London dates had sold out on all primary platforms. 
11.30am 
Approximately 2,365 tickets listed on secondary resale sites for London dates including 1,330 on Viagogo, 120 on StubHub, 700 on GET ME IN! and 215 on Seatwave. 
The price of a ticket across all three dates on secondary sites ranged from £150 to £1,000. Like us on Facebook
